item.title: [Objective-C] App feature;
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“mrnessie, post:11, topic:524385”]i see… i might try to learn c… seems easy enough[/quote]I would like to warn you about the hell you will be getting yourself into. Do not go in with an attitude thinking it will be easy.

xx matty xx:

ok i’ve been staring at this for 10 minutes and can’t understand how you can check if an array is equal to a value in that array… pls somebody spill the beans

what he was saying, you have an integer array defined, but are trying to check for it as an integer itself against (currently) a string.

for one, you need to get your array of dates set up.

http://www.icodeblog.com/2009/08/26/objective-c-tutorial-nsarray/

read that please.
[/quote]Actually, what he’s doing is perfectly fine, since a character literal with multiple characters just changes the value. I read characters are the same size as integers in objective c, but I don’t know if the character value gets truncated or not. Either way, if the value he’s checking fits into one byte, it should work. He isn’t using strings.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: [Objective-C] App feature;
item.dc:creator: @Zeanr Zeanr
item.description:
@Zeanr wrote:

Hello there, moparscape community!

I’m making an app feature where whenever a certain date comes, it will UIAlertView whoever has the app. I’m just curious as to know that what I’ve got now would work once I #import certain date and times functions into the program.

I’m currently using an online compiler as I am waiting for a VGA cord to come so I can hook up my MiniMac.

#include <stdio.h>

int main(){
    int troopEvent[]={'one', 'two', 'three', 'four', 'five'};
    
    if(troopEvent == 'one'){
        UIAlertView *alert = [[UIAlert alloc]
        initWithTitle:@"TITLE"
        message:@"MESSAGE ONE"
        delegate:self
        cancelButtonTitle:@"OK"
        otherButtonTitles:self];
    }
    else if(troopEvent == 'two'){
        UIAlertView *alert = [[UIAlert alloc]
        initWithTitle:@"TITLE"
        message:@"MESSAGE ONE"
        delegate:self
        cancelButtonTitle:@"OK"
        otherButtonTitles:self];
    }
    else if(troopEvent == 'three'){
        UIAlertView *alert = [[UIAlert alloc]
        initWithTitle:@"TITLE"
        message:@"MESSAGE ONE"
        delegate:self
        cancelButtonTitle:@"OK"
        otherButtonTitles:self];
    }
    else if(troopEvent == 'four'){
        UIAlertView *alert = [[UIAlert alloc]
        initWithTitle:@"TITLE"
        message:@"MESSAGE ONE"
        delegate:self
        cancelButtonTitle:@"OK"
        otherButtonTitles:self];
    }
    else if(troopEvent == 'five'){
        UIAlertView *alert = [[UIAlert alloc]
        initWithTitle:@"TITLE"
        message:@"MESSAGE ONE"
        delegate:self
        cancelButtonTitle:@"OK"
        otherButtonTitles:self];
    }
    else{
    }
    return 0;
}

Where the (‘one’, ‘two’, ‘three’, 'four, ‘five’) are in the array is where the dates would be once it’s imported into the program and same goes for the IF statements.

Read full topic
